profile_positions.description: I am responsible for developing, analyzing, and implementing strategies and guidelines that promote scientific research and collaboration among various stakeholders. This role involves translating complex scientific insights into practical policy measures and overseeing initiatives that contribute to the growth and impact of both the scientific and societal community.
profile_positions.title: Programme Coordinator | Policy Officer

profile_positions.description:
I have built large consortia and maintained these networks well for subsidy applications for enzymatic CO2 reduction, of which €40,000 has been awarded. Besides setting up a new line of research in the lab (biophysical group of the TU Berlin)*, I also supervised PhD and master students.

*Development and application of freeze quench and stopped flow techniques for the analysis of protein and/or enzyme samples with a variety of spectroscopic techniques: EPR, resonance Raman, ATR/IR and FT-IR under cryogenic conditions. Subsequent kinetic analysis to obtain for example rate constants. Application of CO releasing molecules for the inhibition of proteins and enzymes.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher

profile_positions.description: Follow up experiments in the lab for potentially new research and finishing of PhD project in the form of publications
profile_positions.title: Guest Researcher

profile_positions.description:
During my PhD research I worked with a wide variety of partners on large research projects. I have worked abroad (Germany, Spain, UK, Switzerland, Poland and France) a lot to perform measurements and calculations that were not possible in our own research lab. All research results have been published in highly regarded scientific journals. 

My PhD focused on the development of  time-resolved methodologies to allow the characterization of all reaction intermediates in time, including short-lived active species. We focused on industrially important systems, like, hydrogen production, ethene selective oligomerization/polymerization and C-C/C-X cross couplings reactions. The influence of the ligand on the catalyst performance is significant for all, but poor mechanistic insights and the lack of structure-reactivity relationships hamper understanding and further development. Detailed spectroscopic studies into the structure and electronics of the catalysts during function are essential to develop these systems in a rational manner.
profile_positions.title: PhD Candidate

profile_positions.description:
Explored the light harvesting and directional energy transfer properties of Perylene Monoimide - Fullerene dyads for the development of for example efficient bulk - heterojunction photovoltaic devices. The donor and acceptor unit were linked by a phenyl ring via a ortho, meta and para -linkage, on its own giving more insight in the orientation effects in energy transfer processes. 

Results showed quantitative intramolecular singlet and triplet energy transfer within all three dyads. The observed distance dependency correspond well with the theoretical Förster and Dexter models and the generated computational data. (Donor fragment optimized in S1, Configuration interaction singles (CIS) using 6 – 31G basis set. Acceptor fragment optimized in ground state with B3LYP/6 – 31G level.  The FED and Coulomb couplings were calculated with CIS/6–31 G. Transition dipole moments were calculated using TD-DFT (B3LYP/6 – 31G).) Techniques used include Steady State Emission and Absorption Spectroscopy, Femtosecond Absorption Spectroscopy, Time Resolved Fluorescence Spectroscopy, Nanosecond Transient Absorption Spectrsocopy, High Pressure Liquid Chromatography.

At the group of Molecular Photonics
profile_positions.title: Graduation Student

profile_positions.description:
My study, Molecular Design, Synthesis and Catalysis at the UvA, courses: 

Organic Chemistry, Inorganic Chemistry, Thermodynamics, Calculus (all HLO Premaster)
Organic Chemistry, Physical Organic Chemistry, Bio-Organic Chemistry,  
Heterogeneous Catalysis, Coordination and Organometallic Chemistry 
Nuclear Magnetic Resonance, Separation Sciences, Molecular Computational Chemistry 
English Academic Course, Academic Skills: Critical Thinking

Literature Thesis and Colloquium: Computational Understanding of Pericyclic Reactions.
profile_positions.title: Master student

profile_positions.description: Physical Chemistry Laboratory, Head - Teaching assistant. Teaching and supervising 	first year physics experiments. Marked assignments and graded students on theoretical and practical aspects.
profile_positions.title: Head Teaching Assistant

profile_positions.description:
Organic Chemistry Laboratory, Supervised and instructed students in Organic 			Chemistry  procedures and techniques. Emphasized the safety regulations mostly by 		discussing the risks and hazards in class. 
		
Introductory and advanced Chemistry, Prepared teaching materials, including problem sets, lecture sheets and exams for first and second year Chemistry bachelor students. Lectures were given weakly  with another assisting student. 

Mentor of first year students, helping them with individual questions regarding the courses or agenda wise.
profile_positions.title: Teaching Assistant

profile_positions.description:
Monitoring the progress and developments of the Applied Science program. Chairman from September 2009 to January  2010.

Structuring, reporting and documenting the meetings of the Program Committee. A few of many functions: approve reports of committee meetings before their distribution. Report to the committee on decisions of the Board or of executive staff that affect the committee's work. Where appropriate, make policy recommendations to the president for transmission to the Board. Keep discussions on track; periodically re-state the issue and the goal of the discussion and close the meetings by stating all achieved goals and follow-up actions.
profile_positions.title: Curriculum Committee

profile_positions.description:
Engineered polymer samples with specific degrees and patterns of methylesterification using both chemical and enzymatic methodolegies. Noteworthy, first de-esterification of apple pectin using base treatment for several days, resulted in higher yields of esterification in the esterification process. By the use of gel electrophoresis, the different samples could be analyzed and discriminated on different methylation patterns, created by different methods. The additional use of H-NMR, confirming the assumptions made on gel-electrophoresis results, made it possible to develop/ increase the library of pectin distributions for future research. The H-NMR measurements involved procedures like suppressing water signals. 

Additional research was conducted towards the covalent coupling of pectin towards a resin for optical tweezers experiment. Several light induced reactions were tested with minimum results. Fluorescent labelling of pectin was accomplished in the desired 1 in a 100 monomers ratio in high yields. A simple purification method was established by ethanol precepatation at low temperatures followed by vacuum-drying. Techniques used in this project are enzyme procedures (pectin Lyase Aspergillus Niger and Orange/plant), chemical procedures involved sulfuric acid., Freeze drying, High – tech Centrifuge using different membranes, Chemical Synthesis, Gel-Electrophoresis, H-NMR, MS-Spectroscopy, IR-Spectroscopy.
profile_positions.title: Graduation

profile_positions.description: The fabrication of a thermal responsive hydrogel, by the use of inverse suspension polymerization for the softening of water. The synthesis of small even distributed hydrogels consisting of neutral thermal sensitive monomers, a crosslinker and a cationic and anionic polymer was successful in high yields. The results showed greatly improved adsorption isotherms (binding affinity / calcium concentration) compared to alternative techniques like bulk-synthesis. Furthermore, the process was optimized (e.g.) by controlling the reaction conditions as water/oil ratio and the equivalent of reactants. The morphology was determined by microscopy, revealing the size distribution of the batches, analyzed by Student's t-distribution. Techniques used in this research: (inverse) Suspension polymerization, (Light) Microscopy, FT-IR, Titrations and calcium binding affinity calculations.
profile_positions.title: Internship
